sections.heading: Spaces and Equal Signs
paragraphs: Avoid unnecessary spaces around equal signs.
Clean formatting improves readability.

sections.heading: Avoid Long Code Lines
paragraphs: Long code lines are hard to read.
Break code into multiple lines for better readability.

sections.heading: Blank Lines and Indentation
paragraphs: Use blank lines to separate logical sections.
Use two spaces for indentation instead of tabs.

Famous Cities

sections.heading: Never Skip the Title Element
paragraphs: The <title> element is required in HTML documents.

The user input is most often sent to a server for processing.

sections.heading: The <form> Element
paragraphs: The <form> element is used to create an HTML form for user input.
It acts as a container for different input elements such as text fields, radio buttons, checkboxes, and submit buttons.

sections.heading: The <input> Element

Its behavior depends on the value of the type attribute.

sections.heading: Text Fields
The <label> Element
paragraphs: The <label> tag defines a label for form elements.
It improves accessibility and usability.
The for attribute must match the id of the input field.

sections.heading: Radio Buttons
paragraphs: Radio buttons allow users to select one option from a group.

sections.heading: Checkboxes
paragraphs: Checkboxes allow users to select zero or more options.

sections.heading: Submit Button
paragraphs: The submit button sends form data to the server.
The form action attribute defines where the data is sent.

sections.heading: The name Attribute
paragraphs: Each input field must have a name attribute.
Without a name, the input value will not be submitted.

The <form> element is the container for form controls
The <input> element has different types

paragraphs: This chapter describes the different attributes for the HTML <form> element.
Form attributes control how form data is sent and processed.

sections.heading: The Action Attribute
paragraphs: The action attribute defines where the form data is sent when the form is submitted.
Usually, the data is sent to a server-side script.

sections.heading: The Target Attribute

table.description: Opens response in a new tab
Opens response in the same window

sections.heading: The Method Attribute
paragraphs: The method attribute specifies how form data is sent.

sections.heading: The Autocomplete Attribute
paragraphs: Specifies whether the browser should automatically complete form values.

sections.heading: The Novalidate Attribute
paragraphs: Disables browser validation when submitting a form.

sections.heading: Chapter Summary
points: The action attribute defines where form data is sent
The target attribute defines where the response is shown
The method attribute defines how data is sent
GET is visible and limited
POST is secure and supports large data
Autocomplete helps fill form fields automatically
Novalidate disables browser validation

paragraphs: This chapter describes all the different HTML form elements.
HTML forms are used to collect user input.

sections.heading: The HTML <form> Element

sections.heading: The <input> Element
paragraphs: The <input> element is one of the most used form elements.
It can be displayed in different ways depending on the type attribute.

sections.heading: The <label> Element
paragraphs: The <label> element defines a label for form elements.
It improves accessibility and usability.
Clicking the label focuses the related input element.

sections.heading: The <select> Element
paragraphs: The <select> element defines a drop-down list.
sections.example:
<label for="cars">Choose a car:</label>
<select id="cars" name="cars">

sections.heading: The <option> Element
paragraphs: The <option> element defines an option in a drop-down list.
The selected attribute defines the default selected option.

sections.heading: Visible Values

sections.heading: Multiple Selection

sections.heading: The <textarea> Element
paragraphs: The <textarea> element defines a multi-line input field.

sections.heading: The <button> Element
paragraphs: The <button> element defines a clickable button.

sections.heading: The <fieldset> and <legend> Elements
paragraphs: The <fieldset> element groups related data in a form.

sections.heading: The <datalist> Element

paragraphs: This chapter describes the different attributes for the HTML <input> element.

sections.description: Specifies an initial value for an input field.

sections.heading: The readonly Attribute
sections.description: Specifies that an input field is read-only and cannot be modified.

sections.heading: The disabled Attribute
sections.description: Specifies that an input field is disabled and unusable.

sections.heading: The size Attribute
sections.description: Specifies the visible width of an input field in characters.

sections.heading: The maxlength Attribute

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The HTML <canvas> element is used to draw graphics on a web page.
The <canvas> element is only a container for graphics. You must use JavaScript to draw the graphics.
Canvas supports drawing paths, boxes, circles, text, and images.

sections.heading: What is HTML Canvas?
paragraphs: The HTML <canvas> element is used to draw graphics on the fly using JavaScript.
Canvas is supported by all major browsers.

sections.heading: Canvas Syntax
sections.note: Always specify an id, width, and height. Use CSS to add borders.

sections.heading: Draw a Line
sections.example:
<script>
var c = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
var ctx = c.getContext("2d");
ctx.moveTo(0, 0);
ctx.lineTo(200, 100);
ctx.stroke();
</script>

sections.heading: Draw a Circle
sections.example:
<script>
var c = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
var ctx = c.getContext("2d");
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.arc(95, 50, 40, 0, 2 * Math.PI);
ctx.stroke();
</script>

sections.heading: Draw Text
sections.example:
<script>
var c = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
var ctx = c.getContext("2d");
ctx.font = "30px Arial";
ctx.fillText("Hello World", 10, 50);
</script>

sections.heading: Stroke Text
sections.example:
<script>
var c = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
var ctx = c.getContext("2d");
ctx.font = "30px Arial";
ctx.strokeText("Hello World", 10, 50);
</script>

sections.heading: Linear Gradient
sections.example:
<script>
var c = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
var ctx = c.getContext("2d");
var grd = ctx.createLinearGradient(0, 0, 200, 0);
grd.addColorStop(0, "red");
grd.addColorStop(1, "white");
ctx.fillStyle = grd;
ctx.fillRect(10, 10, 150, 80);
</script>

sections.heading: Radial Gradient
sections.example:
<script>
var c = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
var ctx = c.getContext("2d");
var grd = ctx.createRadialGradient(75, 50, 5, 90, 60, 100);
grd.addColorStop(0, "red");
grd.addColorStop(1, "white");
ctx.fillStyle = grd;
ctx.fillRect(10, 10, 150, 80);
</script>

sections.heading: Draw Image
sections.example:
<script>
var c = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
var ctx = c.getContext("2d");
var img = document.getElementById("scream");
ctx.drawImage(img, 10, 10);
</script>

sections.heading: Chapter Summary
points: Canvas is used to draw graphics using JavaScript
The <canvas> element itself has no drawing ability
Graphics are created using JavaScript methods
Canvas supports lines, shapes, text, gradients, and images
Canvas works in all modern browsers

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics.
SVG defines vector-based graphics in XML format.
SVG graphics are scalable and do not lose quality when zoomed or resized.
SVG is supported by all major browsers.

sections.heading: What is SVG?
points: SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics
SVG is used to define vector-based graphics for the Web
SVG defines graphics in XML format
Each SVG element can be animated
SVG is a W3C recommendation
SVG works with CSS, DOM, XSL, and JavaScript

sections.heading: The <svg> Element
paragraphs: The <svg> element is a container for SVG graphics.
SVG supports drawing shapes such as paths, rectangles, circles, polygons, and text.

sections.heading: SVG Circle
sections.example:
<svg width="100" height="100">
  <circle cx="50" cy="50" r="40" stroke="green" stroke-width="4" fill="yellow" />
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Rectangle

SVG elements can be styled and animated

Web pages often contain multimedia elements of different types and formats.

Includes images, music, sound, videos, films, and animations
Used widely in modern web pages

sections.heading: Browser Support
paragraphs: Early browsers supported only text.
Modern browsers support colors, fonts, images, audio, and video.

sections.heading: Multimedia Formats

File type can be identified by file extensions like .mp3, .mp4, .avi, etc.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The HTML <video> element is used to show a video on a web page.

sections.heading: HTML Video Element
sections.description: To show a video in HTML, use the <video> element.

example.code:
<video width="320" height="240" controls>
  <source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="movie.ogg" type="video/ogg">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

sections.heading: How It Works
points: The controls attribute adds play, pause, and volume controls.
Width and height should be specified to avoid page flickering.
The <source> element allows multiple video formats.
The browser uses the first supported format.
Fallback text is shown if video is not supported.

sections.heading: Autoplay
sections.description: To start a video automatically, use the autoplay attribute.

example.code:
<video width="320" height="240" autoplay>
  <source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="movie.ogg" type="video/ogg">
</video>

sections.note: Most browsers block autoplay unless the video is muted.

  <source src="movie.ogg" type="video/ogg">
</video>

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Plug-ins are computer programs that extend the standard functionality of the browser.

sections.heading: What Are Plug-ins Used For?
points: To run Java applets
To run Microsoft ActiveX controls
To display Flash movies
To display maps
To scan for viruses
To verify a bank ID

sections.heading: Warning
warnings: Most browsers no longer support Java Applets and Plug-ins.
ActiveX controls are no longer supported in any browsers.
Shockwave Flash is no longer supported in modern browsers.

sections.heading: The <object> Element
description: The <object> element is supported by all browsers.
It defines an embedded object within an HTML document.
It was designed to embed plug-ins such as Java applets, PDF readers, and Flash players.
It can also be used to include HTML inside HTML.

sections.heading: The <embed> Element
description: The <embed> element is supported in all major browsers.
It defines an embedded object inside an HTML document.
It was supported by browsers before HTML5, but not officially part of HTML until HTML5.
The <embed> element does not have a closing tag.
It cannot contain alternative text.

sections.heading: Key Notes
points: The <object> element supports fallback content.
The <embed> element does not support fallback content.
Modern browsers discourage the use of plug-ins.
HTML5 alternatives (audio, video, canvas, SVG) should be used instead.

sections.heading: Chapter Summary
summary: The <object> and <embed> elements are used for embedding content.
Modern HTML favors native multimedia elements instead of plug-ins.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The easiest way to play videos in HTML is to use YouTube.
Converting videos to different formats can be difficult and time-consuming.
Using YouTube allows you to embed videos easily without worrying about format compatibility.

sections.heading: YouTube Video ID
paragraphs: YouTube assigns a unique ID to each video (for example: tgbNymZ7vqY).
This ID is used to embed the video into an HTML page.

sections.heading: Embedding a YouTube Video
steps: Upload the video to YouTube
Copy the video ID
Use an <iframe> element
Set the src attribute to the YouTube embed URL
Define width and height
Add optional parameters

example.title: Basic YouTube Embed
example.code:
<iframe width="420" height="315"
src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/tgbNymZ7vqY">
</iframe>

sections.heading: Autoplay and Mute
paragraphs: You can autoplay a YouTube video using autoplay=1.
Most browsers block autoplay unless the video is muted.
Use mute=1 together with autoplay=1 to allow autoplay.

example.title: Autoplay with Mute
example.code:
<iframe width="420" height="315"
src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/tgbNymZ7vqY?autoplay=1&mute=1">
</iframe>

sections.heading: YouTube Playlist and Loop
paragraphs: You can loop a video by using the playlist parameter.
loop=1 makes the video repeat forever.
The playlist value must be the same as the video ID.

example.title: Loop a Video
example.code:
<iframe width="420" height="315"
src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/tgbNymZ7vqY?playlist=tgbNymZ7vqY&loop=1">
</iframe>

sections.heading: YouTube Controls
paragraphs: You can hide or show video controls.
controls=0 hides the controls.
controls=1 shows the controls (default).

example.title: Disable Controls
example.code:
<iframe width="420" height="315"
src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/tgbNymZ7vqY?controls=0">
</iframe>

sections.heading: Chapter Summary

The video ID is required to embed a video.
Autoplay works only when muted in modern browsers.
Looping and control options can be configured using URL parameters.
YouTube is the easiest way to display videos on web pages.

web-api.title: HTML - What is a Web API?

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: A Web API is a developer's dream.
It can extend the functionality of the browser.
It can greatly simplify complex functions.
It can provide easy syntax to complex code.

sections.heading: What is Web API?
paragraphs: API stands for Application Programming Interface.
An API is an interface that allows programmers to access specific features or data of an application, operating system, or other services.
A Web API is an application programming interface for the Web.

sections.heading: HTML APIs
paragraphs: All browsers have built-in Web APIs to support complex operations and access data.
Some of the main HTML5 APIs are listed below.
list: Geolocation API  Accesses the user's location (latitude and longitude).
Drag and Drop API  Enables drag-and-drop functionality in browsers.
Web Storage API  Stores key/value data in the browser.
Web Workers API  Runs JavaScript in the background without blocking the UI.
Server-Sent Events API  Allows automatic server updates.
Canvas API  Used to draw graphics dynamically using JavaScript.

sections.heading: Notes on Using HTML APIs
points: Always check browser compatibility before using an API.
Add proper error handling to avoid failures.
Request user permission when accessing sensitive data such as location.

sections.heading: Third Party APIs
paragraphs: Third-party APIs are not built into browsers.
They must be downloaded or accessed from external sources.
examples: YouTube API  Display videos on a website.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The Geolocation API is used to get the user's current location.
Since this can compromise privacy, the location is not available unless the user approves it.
The Geolocation API is only available on secure contexts such as HTTPS.
It works best on devices with GPS such as smartphones.

sections.heading: Using HTML Geolocation API
paragraphs: The Geolocation API is accessed using navigator.geolocation.
The browser asks the user for permission before providing location data.
If permission is granted, the device uses GPS or network data to determine location.

sections.heading: getCurrentPosition() Method
sections.description: Returns the current geographic location of the user.

sections.heading: Error Handling
sections.description: Handles errors when location access fails.

sections.heading: watchPosition() Method
sections.description: Tracks the user's location continuously, similar to GPS.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The HTML Drag and Drop API enables an element to be dragged and dropped.
Drag and drop is a very common feature where you grab an object and move it to another location.

sections.heading: Make an Element Draggable
sections.description: To make an element draggable, set the draggable attribute to true.

sections.heading: ondragstart and setData()
sections.description: Defines what data should be dragged.
notes: The value is the ID of the dragged element

sections.heading: ondragover
sections.description: Allows the dragged element to be dropped by preventing default behavior.

sections.heading: ondrop
sections.description: Handles the drop operation.
steps: Prevent default browser behavior
Retrieve dragged data
Append dragged element to drop target

examples.description: Drag an <h1> element into a div.

examples.title: Drag and Drop a Link
examples.description: Drag an <a> element into a div.

examples.title: Drag Image Between Divs
examples.description: Move an image back and forth between two containers.

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: HTML Web Storage API is better than cookies.
Web storage allows applications to store data locally in the user's browser.
Unlike cookies, data is not sent to the server and storage capacity is much larger (at least 5MB).
Web storage is per origin (domain + protocol).

sections.heading: Web Storage Objects
list: window.localStorage  stores data with no expiration date
window.sessionStorage  stores data for one session only

example.code:
<script>
const x = document.getElementById("result");
if (typeof(Storage) !== "undefined") {
  x.innerHTML = "Your browser supports Web storage!";
} else {
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";
}
</script>

sections.heading: localStorage Object
sections.description: Stores data with no expiration date.

example.code:
<script>
const x = document.getElementById("result");

  localStorage.setItem("lastname", "Smith");
  localStorage.setItem("bgcolor", "yellow");
  x.innerHTML = localStorage.getItem("lastname");
  x.style.backgroundColor = localStorage.getItem("bgcolor");
} else {
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";
}
</script>

sections.heading: sessionStorage Object
sections.description: Stores data only for the current browser session. Data is deleted when the tab is closed.

example.code:
<script>

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: A web worker is an external JavaScript file that runs in the background without affecting page performance.
Web workers allow scripts to run independently of the main thread.
They are useful for CPU-intensive tasks.

sections.heading: What is a Web Worker?
paragraphs: When executing scripts in an HTML page, the page becomes unresponsive until the script is finished.
A web worker runs in the background independently.
The UI remains responsive while the worker executes.

example.code:
<script>
const x = document.getElementById("result");
if(typeof(Worker) !== "undefined") {
  x.innerHTML = "Your browser support Web Workers!";
} else {
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, your browser does not support Web Workers.";
}
</script>

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: The Server-Sent Events (SSE) API enables pushing messages or updates from a server to a web page via an HTTP connection.
SSE allows the server to automatically send updates to the client.
This is a one-way communication (server  client).

sections.heading: Explanation
points: Creates an EventSource object connected to a server script
onmessage fires when the server sends data
Received data is accessed using event.data

example.code:
<?php
header('Content-Type: text/event-stream');
header('Cache-Control: no-cache');

$time = date('r');
echo "data: The server time is: {$time}\n\n";
flush();
?>

<%
Response.ContentType = "text/event-stream"
Response.Expires = -1
Response.Write("data: The server time is: " & now())
Response.Flush()
%>

sections.heading: Server-Side Notes
points: Content-Type must be text/event-stream
Caching must be disabled
Each message must begin with 'data:'
Use flush() to send data immediately
